newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong credibility seen hinging on next legislature.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong credibility seen hinging on next legislature.

text.p: The rapid installation of a credible legislature was crucial to retain confidence in Hong Kong's administration after its handover to China, a senior official of the current and future governments said on Monday.
But a leader of the violently-supressed 1989 democracy movement in Beijing said she feared for the future of freedom in Hong Kong once China retakes the British colony on July 1.
Underlining the impending flag change, a second advance guard of 66 troops from the People's Liberation Army (PLA) arrived on Monday to get future garrison facilities ready.
In 43 days, Hong Kong, a capitalist territory of 6.4 million people, reverts to China after 156 years as a British colony.

Hong Kong Chief Secretary Anson Chan said one of the top priorities of the post-July administration was to install a successor to the current legislature, which will cease to exist after Britain hands the territory back to China.

"We have an obligation to the community to ensure that they are represented by a credible and authoritative legislature in which they, and the international community have confidence," Chan said in a speech to business conference in Manila.
"Otherwise, the credibility and authority of the future administration itself will be weakened," she warned.
Chan, who will remain the territory's top civil servant beyond the handover, did not specifically mention the provisional legislature, which will replace the current council on July 1.

The provisional body was chosen by a China-backed committee of 400 last year. The current, elected council will be scrapped because Beijing says electoral rules used in the 1995 polls violated previous Sino-British agreements.

The provisional legislature is expected to be only an interim law-making body to ensure a smooth transition of power in the early days of the handover and will be replaced by some form of elected body in 1998.
Chan noted opinion polls showed that, despite confidence in Hong Kong's economic prospects, many people were less certain about freedoms and civil liberties.

An opinion poll published by the South China Morning Post newspaper on Monday showed Hong Kong's future leader Tung Chee-hwa has suffered a dip in popularity over plans to curb civil rights. Some 41.7 percent of respondents also said they now had less trust in Tung, a former shipping tycoon.
Last month Tung unveiled plans to curb protests and ban foreign funding for political groups in Hong Kong after July 1.
But in a separate poll by Reuters, big Hong Kong companies remained positive about the post-handover business outlook.
Chinese pro-democracy dissident Chai Ling on Monday voiced concern about the future of freedoms in Hong Kong and urged the PLA not to repeat the 1989 massacre of protesters in Beijing.
Chai, one of the leaders of the protests in Beijing's Tiananmen Square, was in Hong Kong for a short, private visit.

"I am very concerned about how much freedom the people in Hong Kong will be allowed to have after July 1," Chai told a news conference. Hong Kong people would have to defend their freedom and liberty inch by inch, she said.
A 66-strong unit of unarmed PLA soldiers drove into Hong Kong on Monday, the second contingent in as many months to arrive.
Forty PLA soldiers came in April to prepare logistics and camp facilities before the eventual arrival on July 1 of the rest of PLA troops to be stationed in the territory.

Major-General Liu Zhenwu, commander of the future Hong Kong garrison, urged the unit "to carry on the fine traditions of the PLA, and to perform the sacred duties entrusted to them by the country and people", official Chinese media reported.
Meanwhile, a new direct train service from the territory to the Chinese capital was launched on Monday, bringing Hong Kong and Beijing ever closer.

"It symbolises...the strengthening ties between Hong Kong and China, which so many people have been longing for," Hong Kong's Financial Secretary Donald Tsang told guests and passengers at the territory's Hung Hom Railway Station.
